awd_titl_txt: Building Community and Capacity for Data-Intensive Evidence-Based Decision Making in Schools and Districts
awd_abstract_narration:
Evidence-based decision making in schools and districts is a growing area of research and practice, in which teachers and administrators come together around their students' data to build capacity and inform instructional decision making.  The goal of this project is to build a researcher-practitioner community around data-intensive evidence-based decision making through bringing together large and diverse school district datasets and then applying recent innovations from the data sciences to pilot and test data analytics with teachers and administrators. This will provide a test-bed and exemplars which will be used to spur capacity building between and among researchers and current school leaders around the data currently in use in their schools.

This study will inform current research and practice around data analytics and evidence-based practice in schools using the data that districts already collect. Research from this project will extend beyond a single discipline, helping to inform a diverse set of research domains, including data science, statistics, education data mining, improvement science, design-based research, education research and social services. Furthermore, this project will bring together researchers and school leaders to build community and capacity around intensive data analytics for educational decision making. The project will publish and release the open source R code. Publishing the code as open access will provide a means to help structure school district education data cycles, as the R code will provide an incentive for districts to store and structure their data in such a way so that they can implement the analytics and visualizations immediately from the code that will be generated in this project.

por.por_cntn:
Nationally, teachers and K-12 school administrators are increasingly encouraged to use data and evidence in their practice to inform instructional and organizational improvement. Concurrently, school districts across the US together spend billions on data technologies, such as instructional data warehouses (IDW) and dashboard systems, with the intention to make the data more accessible and useful for educator decision making. Yet, while there have been many individual case study success stories of school data use with technology, current large-scale research nationally has shown little relationship between school improvement and teacher and administrator use of data technologies. Persistent issues to date in this domain are that a) educator data use for instructional improvement is assumed to be unidimensional, from high to low, yet this is has not been tested with large surveys and pattern analytics, b) there is a lack of information on how educators use instructional data warehouse systems, what they click on, and when, and how this informs data analytics and visualization systems, c) data analytics and visualization systems in schools have traditionally to date not taken advantage of innovations from the data science and big data fields, and d) educator perspectives are rarely included in the data visualization, user interface design, and dashboard creation process. Thus, there is a deep need in the education data analytics domain to surface and understand the data use needs of educators while also building and piloting data analytics and visualizations that address issues around instructional improvement that educators identify.

The goals of this project were to build a researcher-practitioner community around data-intensive evidence-based decision making in schools through bringing together large and diverse school district datasets and then applying recent innovations from the data sciences to pilot and test data analytics with teachers and administrators. This project is a research practice partnership (RPP) between the research organization (Teachers College, Columbia University) (TC) and the New York Nassau County Board of Cooperative Educational Services (Nassau BOCES) which serves the 56 school districts in Nassau County Long Island New York. Nassau BOCES is the organization that maintains the shared IDW across the districts and is a central provider of professional development for educators on data use and improvement for their districts. The goals of the project were to:

1) identify perceptions and needs of teachers and administrators around data use and evidence-based improvement cycles in their schools and districts.

2) identify different patterns of perceptions of data use across the districts and schools.

3) build and test analytics that process and visualize the data in response to stakeholder needs across the districts.

4) bring together the stakeholders around the data and the analytics to iterate on the analytics to address their specific needs for data use for evidence-based improvement cycles.

To do this, we first surveyed 4,941 educators and interviewed a sample of 40 teachers and administrators across the 56 districts on their data use perceptions and actions in schools. We then matched their responses on their data use to the logfile data in the Nassau BOCES data warehouse, identifying four significantly different types of educator data use across the county. We followed up this pattern analysis with 40 individual qualitative interviews, examining teacher and administrator perceptions of effective and ineffective data use, especially in relation to the IDW dashboards and visualizations. We then compared these findings to an analysis of de-identified IDW logfile clickstream data, including about 490,000 educator pageviews in the data dashboard system, identifying different types of information educators are looking for at different times throughout the year, and how clicks differ based on job role (teacher, school administrator) and the identified data use survey typology. In December 2019 we then brought together teachers and administrators with data scientists and education researchers (78 participants total) in an iterative design-based 2-day collaborative event to co-design and modify the analytics to address educator problems of practice and work within their current data dashboards. The intention of this project was to build community and capacity within and between the two organizations to create a test-bed environment in Nassau County Long Island, to create and test data analytic applications around the needs of teachers and administrators, and to lay the foundation for future collaborative projects between school educators, leaders, and data scientists through publishing the results, open access code, and perspectives of both educators and data scientists around data visualization and dashboard innovation in schools to support instructional improvement.


Last Modified: 08/26/2021
Modified by: Alex J Bowers
